description: MCSA Windows 8 (70-688) Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems [reference]. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows 8 covers topics that are “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows desktops in a corporate or enterprise environment. Most people know how to use Windows in a home environment. However, there are many features under the hood that are designed for environments with a large quantity of computers. The MCSA dives in to those and gives the learner a whole new toolbox for ensuring their computing environment is functional and stable.
name: MCSA Windows 8.1 - 70-688
subtitle: Supporting Windows 8.1

episodes.description: MCSA Windows 8 (70-688) Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems [reference]. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows 8 covers topics that are “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows desktops in a corporate or enterprise environment. Most people know how to use Windows in a home environment. However, there are many features under the hood that are designed for environments with a large quantity of computers. The MCSA dives in to those and gives the learner a whole new toolbox for ensuring their computing environment is functional and stable.
episodes.title: Overview of MCSA Windows 8.1 (70-688)
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,003 --> 00:00:05,818
[SOUND] The 70-688 exam

2
00:00:05,818 --> 00:00:13,333
covers supporting Windows 8.1.

3
00:00:13,333 --> 00:00:17,956
It's the second step, and really, the,
the last step in obtaining your MCSA for

4
00:00:17,956 --> 00:00:18,700
Windows 8.

5
00:00:18,700 --> 00:00:20,140
Now remember the MCSA,

6
00:00:20,140 --> 00:00:24,550
that's the Microsoft Certified Solutions
Associate And it's designed to serve

7
00:00:24,550 --> 00:00:28,120
as that, that mid level certification for
somebody who's going to going to be

8
00:00:28,120 --> 00:00:33,580
working with desktops in a large or
enterprise business environment, right?

9
00:00:33,580 --> 00:00:37,900
For home users, small office,
home office type deployments,

10
00:00:37,900 --> 00:00:41,720
the technologies that we learn in the
MCSA Windows 8 are usually not practical.

11
00:00:41,720 --> 00:00:44,250
It's a little bit overkill for
small environments, but

12
00:00:44,250 --> 00:00:47,760
if you're dealing with hundreds or
thousands of desktops, we learn about

13
00:00:47,760 --> 00:00:52,800
a lot of things in the MCSA for Windows 8
that is very useful and very practical.

14
00:00:52,800 --> 00:00:56,990
Now, keep in mind that supporting
Windows 8.1 is the second exam.

15
00:00:56,990 --> 00:01:01,920
You should start with the first one,
which is the 70-687,

16
00:01:01,920 --> 00:01:05,240
and that one's gonna kind of move
us along on the certification.

17
00:01:05,240 --> 00:01:07,440
So, let, let's take a look at
that track before we get too far.

18
00:01:09,030 --> 00:01:11,920
The MCSA, the Microsoft Certified
Solutions Associate, there,

19
00:01:11,920 --> 00:01:14,500
there's actually a number of different
tracks that are inside of there

20
00:01:14,500 --> 00:01:16,130
depending on what you want to do.

21
00:01:16,130 --> 00:01:18,460
So, for example, if you want to
learn about server technologies,

22
00:01:18,460 --> 00:01:22,870
they've got the MCSA for Windows Server
2008 And Windows Server 2012.

23
00:01:22,870 --> 00:01:26,030
Those focus on the server side,
and while there is a little bit of

24
00:01:26,030 --> 00:01:30,880
client activity in there, the exams
are really focused on the servers.

25
00:01:30,880 --> 00:01:35,280
On the desktop side, there's the MCSA for
Windows 8 and the MCSA for Windows 7.

26
00:01:35,280 --> 00:01:38,260
And, these again are for
businesses that are being,

27
00:01:38,260 --> 00:01:40,980
that are deploying large
quantities of Windows machines and

28
00:01:40,980 --> 00:01:44,570
they need to be able to manage,
maintain and support them.

29
00:01:44,570 --> 00:01:47,050
Now what we're covering is the MCSA for
Windows 8.

30
00:01:47,050 --> 00:01:48,188
And if you dive into that,

31
00:01:48,188 --> 00:01:51,830
you'll see that there's basically
two exams that make up that track.

32
00:01:51,830 --> 00:01:54,590
The first one is the 70-687
that I mentioned a moment ago.

33
00:01:54,590 --> 00:01:59,330
That's configuring Windows 8.1 and it
focuses on getting Windows 8 installed or

34
00:01:59,330 --> 00:02:02,270
deployed in your environment and
getting it up and running.

35
00:02:02,270 --> 00:02:05,090
In 688, we take that same knowledge and

36
00:02:05,090 --> 00:02:09,140
now we say how do we keep
things running nice and smooth?

37
00:02:09,140 --> 00:02:11,958
But its hard to keep things running
if you didn't get them running in

38
00:02:11,958 --> 00:02:12,707
the first place.

39
00:02:12,707 --> 00:02:14,360
So that's why the 70-687 is first.

40
00:02:14,360 --> 00:02:18,385
You can take them out of
order if you want, but

41
00:02:18,385 --> 00:02:21,250
if you're learning about this,
it doesn't make sense.

42
00:02:21,250 --> 00:02:25,470
You're taking the, the second part of
the exam first, but if you already have

43
00:02:25,470 --> 00:02:27,660
the knowledge it doesn't really
matter which order you take them in.

44
00:02:27,660 --> 00:02:30,510
So Microsoft doesn't care what
order you do them in, but

45
00:02:30,510 --> 00:02:33,680
you typically do want
to stay with the order.

46
00:02:33,680 --> 00:02:36,880
All right now the 688 exam is
packed full of good information.

47
00:02:36,880 --> 00:02:38,500
It can be a little misleading though.

48
00:02:38,500 --> 00:02:40,000
If we take a look at like 687,

49
00:02:40,000 --> 00:02:44,960
and we look at its exam, it's divided
up into seven different areas.

50
00:02:44,960 --> 00:02:48,910
If we find those down here, we'll see all
the different areas that are covered.

51
00:02:48,910 --> 00:02:53,510
And they all take like 10 to 15% of
the exam, except for remote access and

52
00:02:53,510 --> 00:02:56,360
mobility, which is 15 to 20%.

53
00:02:56,360 --> 00:02:59,300
When we take a look at 688,
it's a lot different.

54
00:02:59,300 --> 00:03:04,080
The 688 exam is only divided into three
sections and each one is weighted for

55
00:03:04,080 --> 00:03:05,660
about a third of the exam.

56
00:03:05,660 --> 00:03:09,510
So it looks like a smaller exam,
but it is not.

57
00:03:09,510 --> 00:03:11,630
Each one of these are just larger topics.

58
00:03:11,630 --> 00:03:14,580
The amount of knowledge is about the same,
so don't underestimate it.

59
00:03:14,580 --> 00:03:16,810
Don't think that this is a small and
easy exam.

60
00:03:16,810 --> 00:03:19,760
It's actually one of the more
difficult exams that Microsoft has,

61
00:03:19,760 --> 00:03:23,050
because it covers a lot of technologies
that people aren't familiar with.

62
00:03:23,050 --> 00:03:26,070
In Windows 8 there were a lot of new
troubleshooting technologies that

63
00:03:26,070 --> 00:03:26,720
were introduced.

64
00:03:26,720 --> 00:03:28,340
And, you've gotta learn them, right?

65
00:03:28,340 --> 00:03:30,980
That's part of staying up to date.

66
00:03:30,980 --> 00:03:34,210
So if we look at each of these, the first
one is supporting operating system and

67
00:03:34,210 --> 00:03:36,090
application installation.

68
00:03:36,090 --> 00:03:39,210
Well we did operating system and
installation, or

69
00:03:39,210 --> 00:03:42,980
application installation, in the 70-687,
why do we see this again?

70
00:03:42,980 --> 00:03:45,505
Well it's supporting it,
troubleshooting it,

71
00:03:45,505 --> 00:03:48,255
handling issues that may
arise as a part of it.

72
00:03:48,255 --> 00:03:52,505
So this is much more of a ongoing
operation than the original deployments we

73
00:03:52,505 --> 00:03:56,095
saw in the other one, and you'll see some
of those new technologies jumping out,

74
00:03:56,095 --> 00:03:58,890
like user experience virtualization,
right, UEV.

75
00:03:58,890 --> 00:04:02,430
Not a lot of people have worked
with that because it's fairly new,

76
00:04:02,430 --> 00:04:05,970
so these are some of the things that
have been kind of, kind of added in,

77
00:04:05,970 --> 00:04:07,680
that we've got to take the time to learn.

78
00:04:07,680 --> 00:04:10,730
And you'll also see the Windows Store and
cloud apps.

79
00:04:10,730 --> 00:04:13,520
A lot of Internet-based technology
is being brought into this.

80
00:04:13,520 --> 00:04:20,400
So definitely a, a different angle of, of
approaching the same topics from 70-687.

81
00:04:20,400 --> 00:04:23,610
The second section is supporting
resources access and so

82
00:04:23,610 --> 00:04:27,935
we start diving into some advanced things
that can influence sharing resources,

83
00:04:27,935 --> 00:04:30,195
you know, files, folders and printers.

84
00:04:30,195 --> 00:04:33,875
We'll talk about DNS security,
ways to ratchet that up, remote access,

85
00:04:33,875 --> 00:04:34,785
and, and so on.

86
00:04:34,785 --> 00:04:38,980
You'll notice how all this is kind of
lining up with what was in 70-687,

87
00:04:38,980 --> 00:04:39,960
just going a little more advanced.

88
00:04:41,270 --> 00:04:45,849
And then lastly we get supporting
Windows clients and devices,

89
00:04:45,849 --> 00:04:48,960
which is really a catch-all section.

90
00:04:48,960 --> 00:04:51,790
It goes through quite a few different
steps of troubleshooting and

91
00:04:51,790 --> 00:04:55,220
isolating problems, and how to correct
them, and getting things up and going.

92
00:04:55,220 --> 00:05:00,130
So from things like, the boot manager and
how to analyze stop errors all the way

93
00:05:00,130 --> 00:05:04,440
through mobile devices and
even compliance, policy enforcement.

94
00:05:04,440 --> 00:05:06,740
So there's some really neat things there.

95
00:05:06,740 --> 00:05:11,480
This last one really starts to dabble
into the server side of things and

96
00:05:11,480 --> 00:05:14,470
how we can use servers to
manage those Windows 8 clients.

97
00:05:14,470 --> 00:05:17,800
So it really does serve as that
bridge into Windows Server 2012.

98
00:05:17,800 --> 00:05:23,335
There is also a,
a section on Windows Intune which is a,

99
00:05:23,335 --> 00:05:28,120
a cloud based management solution that
not a lot of people have worked with.

100
00:05:28,120 --> 00:05:29,256
Well it's on the exam.

101
00:05:29,256 --> 00:05:31,849
You need to get exposed to it and
understand it, if for

102
00:05:31,849 --> 00:05:35,951
no other reason then to determine whether
or not it's right for your organization.

103
00:05:35,951 --> 00:05:39,580
All right?
So the 70-688, it covers a lot of stuff.

104
00:05:39,580 --> 00:05:43,690
It is a, a big exam and
it's a lot of new stuff for people,

105
00:05:43,690 --> 00:05:45,470
even if you were certified
under Windows 7.

106
00:05:45,470 --> 00:05:48,750
There's just a lot of new things
that have been added since then.

107
00:05:48,750 --> 00:05:50,850
So it is, a bit of a challenge.

108
00:05:50,850 --> 00:05:51,400
Right?

109
00:05:51,400 --> 00:05:52,950
You gotta hit the books and study hard,

110
00:05:52,950 --> 00:05:55,690
and make sure you learn each of
the concepts that are in there.

111
00:05:55,690 --> 00:05:57,710
And that's what our show's
designed to help with.

112
00:05:57,710 --> 00:06:01,740
So in our 70-688 show, we take all of
those topics and we break them down into

113
00:06:01,740 --> 00:06:05,040
episodes that we can cover it and
make sure that you understand

114
00:06:05,040 --> 00:06:07,930
the technologies and are able to
implement those successfully on the exam.

115
00:06:07,930 --> 00:06:12,090
Now the 70-688 exam is just like
every other Microsoft exam.

116
00:06:12,090 --> 00:06:14,140
It's a hundred and
fifty dollars to take it and

117
00:06:14,140 --> 00:06:16,940
you take it at
a Pearson VUE Testing Center.

118
00:06:16,940 --> 00:06:19,360
Pearson VUE has centers
all over the world, so

119
00:06:19,360 --> 00:06:21,680
you can likely find one very close to you.

120
00:06:21,680 --> 00:06:27,550
You can go to their website,
it's www.pearsonvue.com, that's V-U-E,

121
00:06:27,550 --> 00:06:31,140
and if you add a slash Microsoft to the
end you will go right to Microsoft's page,

122
00:06:31,140 --> 00:06:36,620
you are going to locate a testing center
near you and sign up and take the exam.

123
00:06:36,620 --> 00:06:40,982
When you successfully
pass both the 70-687 and

124
00:06:40,982 --> 00:06:45,160
70-688 exam,
you'll be awarded the MCSA Windows 8.

125
00:06:45,160 --> 00:06:46,660
It's a great certification to have.

126
00:06:46,660 --> 00:06:51,850
It shows employers that you understand
how to deploy and maintain Windows 8 and,

127
00:06:51,850 --> 00:06:55,380
it gets you prepared to be ready for the
next version of Windows that comes out.

128
00:06:55,380 --> 00:06:56,980
So when Windows 10 comes out,

129
00:06:56,980 --> 00:06:59,780
you've already learned the bulk of
what's gonna be on those exams too.

130
00:06:59,780 --> 00:07:01,460
So it is a great certification.

131
00:07:01,460 --> 00:07:04,100
Really kinda pushes you along
in a general direction.

132
00:07:04,100 --> 00:07:06,080
Now if you're just getting
started out in IT,

133
00:07:06,080 --> 00:07:10,760
the MCSA is not really a starting
out certification, so for you,

134
00:07:10,760 --> 00:07:15,770
you might wanna start with, CompTIA A+ if
you've already got computer knowledge.

135
00:07:15,770 --> 00:07:18,620
If you don't have computer knowledge
you might want to start with CompTIA IT

136
00:07:18,620 --> 00:07:23,700
Fundamentals or the Microsoft Technology
Association, the MTA certification.

137
00:07:23,700 --> 00:07:26,100
In there we start with Windows
7 at a basic level and

138
00:07:26,100 --> 00:07:28,870
cover things like installations and
basic support.

139
00:07:28,870 --> 00:07:30,190
Not very high level.

140
00:07:30,190 --> 00:07:34,260
If you've got even, even a handful
of months of experience working with

141
00:07:34,260 --> 00:07:39,110
computers you might find the MTA content
a little bit, I'm going to say, boring.

142
00:07:39,110 --> 00:07:41,670
It's not that it's boring, it's just
that you already know the content.

143
00:07:41,670 --> 00:07:42,210
Right?

144
00:07:42,210 --> 00:07:45,092
So, for you, you move up,
you go into the MCSA.

145
00:07:45,092 --> 00:07:46,370
All right?

146
00:07:46,370 --> 00:07:50,910
Now what many people chose to do is to
do the MCSA for Windows 8 as a client.

147
00:07:50,910 --> 00:07:53,980
And then also do the MCSA for
Windows Server.

148
00:07:53,980 --> 00:07:57,440
And that's a great idea because
you get the best of both worlds.

149
00:07:57,440 --> 00:07:58,980
And by understanding the server and

150
00:07:58,980 --> 00:08:01,780
client technologies you can integrate
them better in a workplace.

151
00:08:01,780 --> 00:08:03,690
So that makes you a more
valuable employee.

152
00:08:03,690 --> 00:08:05,890
Not just to your company, but
to your coworkers, right?

153
00:08:05,890 --> 00:08:06,650
You can.

154
00:08:06,650 --> 00:08:10,110
Properly deploy solutions that
are effective and stay running, and

155
00:08:10,110 --> 00:08:11,620
that's really the goal
of an IT technician.

156
00:08:12,840 --> 00:08:14,780
All right, so,
if that sounds exciting to you,

157
00:08:14,780 --> 00:08:16,860
sounds like what you want to learn,
then you're in the right place.

158
00:08:16,860 --> 00:08:21,250
Stay tuned, our episodes for
70-688 are starting here in just a moment.

159
00:08:21,250 --> 00:08:24,330
if this is the wrong place for
you, you know, it's no big deal.

160
00:08:24,330 --> 00:08:27,150
Jump over to one of the other
certifications that I suggested.

161
00:08:27,150 --> 00:08:30,290
For the server side, you're looking for
the MCSA Windows Server so

162
00:08:30,290 --> 00:08:35,300
those start with the 70-410 exam so
you wanna go and find that show.

163
00:08:35,300 --> 00:08:37,890
If you're starting out
a little more basic than this,

164
00:08:37,890 --> 00:08:41,970
then you want to check out the CompTIA A+
if you have some experience, or

165
00:08:41,970 --> 00:08:45,510
the CompTIA IT Fundamentals
if you have no experience.

166
00:08:45,510 --> 00:08:47,850
And, if you want to stick with
Microsoft there's the MTA,

167
00:08:47,850 --> 00:08:51,390
the Microsoft Technology Associate
which again, if you have no experience,

168
00:08:51,390 --> 00:08:53,010
great place to start.

169
00:08:53,010 --> 00:08:57,180
But if you're looking for desktops,
then it's MCSA Windows 8 all the way.

170
00:08:57,180 --> 00:09:01,829
So let's go ahead and get started, and,
if I don't see you before your exam,

171
00:09:01,829 --> 00:09:02,542
good luck.

172
00:09:02,542 --> 00:09:07,611
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don take a look at advanced installation techniques for Windows 8.1. They discuss supporting Windows To Go as well as creating custom installation images and how to deploy them.
episodes.title: Supporting OS Installation

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Nate take a look at application compatibility and coexistence. They discuss and demonstrate the components required for App-V and UE-V and ACT. They also discuss the functionality of RemoteApp and Hyper-V.
episodes.title: Support Desktop Apps

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Nate take a look at supporting Windows Store and cloud apps. They demonstrate various methods to install apps such as Office 365 and Windows Intune. They also show how to sideload Windows Store apps as well as integrating a Microsoft account.
episodes.title: Supporting Apps

topics.title: Support operating system and application installation

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don discuss file and folder permissions. They take a detailed look at all of the associated permissions as well as how they interact in associated combinations.
episodes.title: Manage Data Security

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don talk about IP addressing issues including subnetting and supernetting. They also identify common issues dealing with name resolution and their solutions including Peer Name Resolution Protocol (PNRP) and DNSSEC.
episodes.title: Support Network Connectivity

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Ronnie discuss network security using Windows Firewall and IP security. They describe methods to restrict applications using inbound and outbound rules with Windows Firewall with Advanced Security as well as securing traffic between two endpoints using IPSec in the Connection Security Rules.
episodes.title: Network Security

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Ronnie discuss the qualities and potential pitfalls of implementing Encrypting File System (EFS) to secure files and folders on a NTFS drive and demonstrate its use. They show encrypting a file and how it restricts access to other users and the use of cipher.exe to create a data recovery agent.
episodes.title: EFS and Data Recovery

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Ronnie take the opportunity to show two networking technologies that Windows 8.1 users may need to use: HomeGroup and Workplace Join.  They talk about scenarios in which you may choose to use either technologies and show the basic configuration of both as well as discuss some issues you may encounter in troubleshooting.
episodes.title: Workplace Join and Homegroups

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Ronnie discuss the usage and management of removable storage devices on Windows 8.1.  They show all of the device managements features found in the local policy as well as demonstrate how to use them in conjunction with each other to make an effective policy for managing remote devices.
episodes.title: Removable Media Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie identify data storage options that Windows 8.1 supports natively and talk about issues creating them and connecting with them.  They specifically show the creation and management of storage spaces.  They identify the common uses of Branchcache and configure the client to connect to a Branchcache server.  They talk about the benefits of using DFS and identify some of the command line utilities to verify its operation. Lastly, they mention the differences between SkyDrive(OneDrive) and SkyDrive Pro
episodes.title: Supporting Data Storage

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie focus on Bitlocker support for Windows 8.1 users.  They briefly review Bitlocker and Bitlocker-To-Go technology.  They describe scenarios for recovering bitlocker encrpyted drives including manually using the password stored as a file, the use of a data recovery agent and group policy and Microsoft Bitlocker Administrating and Monitoring.
episodes.title: BitLocker

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie talk about some of the different authentication methods that are supported in Windows 8.1.  The methods include, virtual smart cards, certificates, picture passwords and use of biometric authentication which are native supported in Windows 8.1.  They discuss common issues using local accounts, domain accounts and Microsoft accounts.
episodes.title: Authentication and Authorization

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don discuss the process of supporting various solutions of remote access. They demonstrate how to leverage the Connection Manager Administration Kit (CMAK) to rollout VPN access to users. They also cover Remote Desktop Services Gateway access as well as verifying the status of Network Access Protection from the client side.
episodes.title: Support Remote Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie discuss and demonstrate the usage of tools and utilities to help support client compliance.  They go into the individual utilites to configure them as well as show how compliance is set through local group policies and Windows Intune.
episodes.title: Support Client Compliance

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Ronnie demonstrate the use of Windows Intune to manage users and devices from cloud based management services. They describe and show how to create users and add computers to the service as well as look at other Intune management possibilities.
episodes.title: Managing Clients with Intune

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie discuss supporting mobile devices within business setting.  They use Windows Intune show how a business can integrate BYODs without being part of a Microsoft domain network. They demonstrate using not only Windows Intune but also Sync settings with Offline Files and Work Folders to allow users access to files even while a Windows 8.1 computer is not within the business LAN.
episodes.title: Supporting Mobile Devices

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don take a look at using Recovery tools built into Windows 8.1 Operating System.  They show and demonstrate the use of some of the most common tools such as Task Manager, Device Manager and discuss the scenarios in which we might choose them.  They also show the usage of the enterprise tool found on MDOP (Microsoft Deployment Operations and Planning Kit) called the DaRT (Diagnostic and Recovery Toolkit) for the purpose of diagnosing a computer that will not even startup after a failure.
episodes.title: Supporting OS and Hardware
